title: I want to write more songs. What is the best way to come up with lyrics and medleys? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m going to skip repeating what other people have said, since I’ve used all of their advice at various times across the years. Mario’s “go out and LIVE, and it will inspire you!”, Madi’s “hum to yourself in a quiet room; get a tune and freestyle”, Steve’s “learn the structure and keep even what you think is bad”, Syd’s “record or write down everything”, Matt’s “write constantly, even when you’re blocked”. You’re asking for “the best way”. I’m sorry to tell you, there isn’t one. But there is a “best way for you…at this time”. That is, there will be ways that work better for you some years, and other ways that will work for you better other years. Why the emphasis? Because other people will have other ways that work better for them at the same time as you do. But that means you just need to take their advice and play around with it until you find the one that works constantly, with a great amount of output. Then when the output dries up…you go do another method and keep playing around with it. In my opinion, medleys are a little easier than lyrics (because they follow rules), but lyrics are also very easy. For medleys, you need to know the tricks of transition, which is a theory-based thing. Existing songs (I’m assuming you’re doing cover medleys) have four things that differ between them: tempo, key signature, time signature, and chord structure. For tempo, accelerando and ritardando exist - not precisely a problem unless the change is incredibly dramatic. Key signatures are helpful if they’re right next to each other (see barbershop songs for an example of medley technique, and there’s a Whitney Houston song that changes key I think four times in succession for examples), or the two songs that you’re melding at that section have similar or identical chord structures i.e. Axis of Awesome - 4 Four Chord Song (with song titles). Time signature is probably the biggest problem, but most pop songs are 4/4 these days so not an issue, and 4/4 to 6/8 isn’t a hard transition regardless - and 3/4 and 6/8 are closely linked. Whether you do transition bars or segue (as in EDM), this is more of a technical skill rather than an artistic one (though arguably it contains some artistry.) You can apply the same skill to original songs, too. If you’re doing lyrics, my way of doing things, to again mixed success over the years, is the same way that I do poems. I get something inspirational (beautiful art), put it in front of me, have a message, intention, or concept that I want to say, and then write a text that rhymes. I’ve used the exact same concept repeatedly, especially on bad days, and because the picture changes, the words change too. Or the concept changes, and so the words change too. And because there are a million, or more, pictures out there, I never run out of inspiration, I only ever run out of time. And some days, maybe I have bad concepts, so I’ll go back to older works, remember those concepts, and use them instead. That’s the end of my answer.  But let me use an example, yes? To explain my way further?  http://zandraart.tumblr.com [Alexandra Kern] Concept I’m using is “the city shines like gemstones and sunset, I’m seeing this for the first time through your eyes” Random key signature: G major, chords are tentatively I-IV-V-I which is G, C, D, G. Left behind the diamonds, in their earthly tombsleft behind the shadows of evening in their gloomLeft behind the sun and its bright unlikely glareAll of that I left to fade into thin air But I’m seeing the city again through the smokescreen and the lightof pollution that blocks the stars, it’s what’s in your eyesI’m walking along hand in hand, smiling at your grinThe joie de vivre, you have to have, to live in the city that we’re in I’ve walked the streets with fear, with decadence and alone,Seen the underbelly of the beast I call my home,Behind York Street there’s a gang of men with sunglasses and foam,Who throw out the owners of new restaurants who don’t Work the way they do But I’m seeing the city again through the smokescreen and the lightof pollution that blocks the stars, it’s what’s in your eyesWalking along with you, hand in hand, I’m smiling at your grinThe joie de vivre, you have to have, to live in the city that we’re in Gunfire - smoking along the stretch of streets.Blood diamonds - they drain the places where traffic meets.Slaves and people who dream of white lines, Accountants locked behind tax and battlelinesKids who grow up too soon but too blindNothing but terror, a place to leave behind But I’m seeing the city again through the smokescreen and the lightof pollution that blocks the stars, it’s the gemstones in your eyesI’m walking along hand in hand, smiling at your grinIt’s the gemstones and sunsets, the beauty of neon, the joy at the city that we live in Walking, rubber-band bass, melancholy gritty singer, practically spoken, e.g. Leonard Cohen, possibly with unexpected chord changes. Could be duetted. Heavy cymbal use for drums, but light taps, more jazz drums than rock drums. As a first draft, it’s kind of terrible, but with more practice it could be something. Done, and that’s a song in 10 minutes.

The answers so far have been good. I don’t agree with the one that said”throw away the bad” though. I don’t throw anything I’ve written away. I just finished two songs for which I wrote the choruses about 30 years ago. I was stuck, so they were just ‘junk’ choruses, right? I’m glad I hung on to them. As to how to write melodies and lyrics: Get some basic books on songwriring and learn the basic song forms, learn about rhyming schemes, what makes a chorus ‘good’, etc.Write. A lot.Listen to music and think about the melodies and lyrics - What makes rhem tick?Read and travel. That wll expand your vocabulary and your imagination.learn the basics of music theory: scales, triads, and chords. Will help a lot in the melody department.Don’t get hung up about what comes first: chords, melody, or lyrics. I’ve done all three. Do what works for you on that particular song.I hope this has been helpful to someone!
